summary: This document is a series of emails from whistleblower Christopher Dilorio to various judges and officials, primarily alleging widespread SEC corruption and obstruction. Dilorio claims the SEC is facilitating massive securities fraud, money laundering, and illegal naked short selling by entities like Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS, while denying his whistleblower awards. He cites specific cases like IMDS, AQR, Cemtrex, FTE Networks, and Parallax Health Sciences as examples of SEC-enabled fraud.

persons.name: Christopher Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, alleging massive SEC corruption, obstruction of his whistleblower claims, and facilitation of securities fraud and money laundering.

persons.name: Paul Levenson
persons.context: Accused by Dilorio of criminally and corruptly obstructing investigations, specifically in the IMDS and AQR cases, and covering up illegal activity.

persons.name: Trevor Milton
persons.context: Mentioned as being indicted by the SDNY and SEC for misleading investors, while allegedly selling $100 million in stock.

persons.name: Linda Grable
persons.context: Barred individual accused, along with Alan Schwartz, of executing a fraudulent stock purchase agreement (SPA) with Viable International for IMDS.

persons.name: Alan Schwartz
persons.context: Barred individual accused, along with Linda Grable, of executing a fraudulent SPA with Viable International for IMDS.

persons.name: Grable II
persons.context: Claimed to have executed the Viable SPA alone, but Dilorio alleges Schwartz and Linda Grable were also involved.

persons.name: Dick Best
persons.context: Accused by Dilorio of crafting incomplete complaints (e.g., Cemtrex/Govil case) that intentionally omit key details like money laundering to protect criminals.

persons.name: Lara Shalov Mehraban
persons.context: Accused alongside Dick Best of filing a limited complaint against Cemtrex/Govil that omits money laundering and key facts.

persons.name: John M. Fife
persons.context: Described as a prolific 'bag man' who invested in known money laundering shells like Cemtrex and FTE Networks; charged by the SEC in 2020.

persons.name: Aron Govil
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for fraud involving Cemtrex and Telidyne, including false claims about COVID-19 apps and crypto transactions.

persons.name: Kevin Goodman
persons.context: Mentioned as the author of a 'bullshit order handling complaint' and later involved in the Parallax COVID-19 disclosure case; accused of obstruction.

persons.name: Ofer Abarbanel
persons.context: Subject of an SEC complaint for allegedly transferring $102 million from 'Investor Group A' into NARL/State Fund accounts.

persons.name: Nicholas Abbate
persons.role: COO of State Funds/New York Alaska
persons.context: Former Knight Capital market maker; controlled 40% of the State Fund that received the $102 million in the Abarbanel case, but omitted from SEC complaint.

persons.name: Michael Beys
persons.role: Former EDNY Prosecutor, FTE Networks CEO
persons.context: Interim/CEO of FTE Networks, involved in what Dilorio alleges is a money laundering shell.

persons.name: Alex Szkaradek
persons.context: Convicted NY felon sued by NY AG for predatory lending; involved in FTE Networks' acquisition of US Home Rentals.

persons.name: Antoni Szkaradek
persons.context: Associated with Alex Szkaradek in the Vision Property Management and FTE Networks dealings.

persons.name: Paul Arena
persons.context: Charged by the SEC for misleading COVID-19 disclosures; known to SEC and New Mexico regulators for other shell companies.

persons.name: Nathaniel Bradley
persons.context: Charged alongside Paul Arena for misleading COVID-19 disclosures.

persons.name: Steve Girsky
persons.context: Mentioned as a SPAC sponsor for Nikola (VectoIQ) and associated with AQR, accused of being 'fooled' or complicit in frauds.

persons.name: Frederick L. Sharp
persons.context: Named in an SEC complaint (Levenson) for involvement in alleged money laundering OTCM shells.

persons.name: Jed S. Rakoff
persons.context: Signed a stipulated order and final judgment in a NYAG/DFS case against Vision Property Management.

persons.name: Mary Kay Vyskocil
persons.context: Dismissed a derivative lawsuit against FTE Networks executives.

connections.description: Dilorio accuses Levenson of criminally obstructing his whistleblower investigations and covering up fraud in cases like IMDS and AQR.
Levenson's SEC Boston brought a complaint against Grable (and Schwartz) for fraud at IMDS, which Dilorio claims was a cover-up.
Both were barred individuals who Dilorio alleges executed a fraudulent SPA with Viable International for IMDS.
SEC New York colleagues jointly accused by Dilorio of filing incomplete complaints (e.g., Cemtrex/Govil) that protect criminals.
Fife is cited as an 'investor' (bag man) in Govil's company Cemtrex, which Dilorio alleges is a money laundering shell.
Abarbanel transferred $102 million to accounts of State Fund/NARL, where Abbate was COO and controlled a significant portion.
Szkaradek's company US Home Rentals was acquired by FTE Networks, where Beys became CEO; involved in promissory notes.
Both charged by the SEC for misleading COVID-19 disclosures related to Parallax Health Sciences.
Dilorio claims Goodman obstructed his claims and authored weak complaints (e.g., Parallax) to allow criminal activity to continue.
Girsky's VectoIQ was a SPAC sponsor for Nikola, founded by Milton, who was later charged with fraud.

events.title: Dilorio Files Knight/UBS TCR
events.description: Christopher Dilorio submits his TCR (Tip, Complaint or Referral) with Berger Montague to the SEC, detailing illegal trading activity in IMDS and other shells by Knight Capital (NITE) and UBS.

events.title: IMDS-Viable International SPA
events.description: Barred individuals Linda Grable and Alan Schwartz, along with Grable II, execute a Stock Purchase Agreement with Viable International for 37 billion shares of IMDS, which Dilorio alleges was unauthorized and used to cover naked short fails.

events.title: Key Tronic Exposes Cemtrex Fraud
events.description: Key Tronic Corporation issues a public response denying any relationship with Cemtrex and calling its acquisition announcement a fraud, a fact omitted from later SEC complaints.

events.title: FTE Acquires US Home Rentals
events.description: FTE Networks acquires US Home Rentals (Vision Property Management) from Alex and Antoni Szkaradek for $350 million in stock and notes, which Dilorio alleges is part of a money laundering scheme.

events.title: SEC Charges John Fife
events.description: SEC files charges against John M. Fife and his companies for acquiring and selling over 21 billion shares of penny stock without registering as a dealer. Dilorio claims this was based on his information.

events.title: SEC Charges Aron Govil (Cemtrex/Telidyne)
events.description: SEC files charges against Aron Govil for fraud involving Cemtrex and Telidyne, including false claims about COVID-19 apps and crypto. Dilorio argues the complaint omits money laundering and key facts.

events.title: AQR/Bit Brother Direct Offering
events.description: AQR-related money laundering shell Bit Brother (fka Urban Tea) completes a $22.5 million direct offering. Dilorio cites this as evidence of ongoing SEC-facilitated fraud.

events.title: Trevor Milton Sells Nikola Stock
events.description: Reports indicate Trevor Milton sold $77 million in Nikola stock after pleading not guilty to fraud charges, which Dilorio cites as an example of SEC inaction.

keyFacts: Christopher Dilorio, a whistleblower, alleges the SEC is a 'grossly corrupt, criminal organization' that actively facilitates massive securities fraud, money laundering, and illegal naked short selling while obstructing his claims and denying him awards.

Dilorio provides detailed allegations about the IMDS case, where he claims the SEC (via Paul Levenson) covered up a scheme involving 37 billion unauthorized shares to bail out Knight Capital (NITE) from naked short positions.

The emails cite multiple specific companies (AQR/CIS/Delta/Urban Tea, Cemtrex, FTE Networks, Parallax Health Sciences) as examples of 'money laundering shells' that the SEC allows to operate despite red flags.

Dilorio asserts that SEC complaints (e.g., against Cemtrex/Govil, FTE executives, Parallax) are intentionally limited and omit key players, money laundering allegations, and facts (like the Key Tronic letter) to protect criminals and ensure the fraud continues.

The document claims the SEC's Office of the Whistleblower (OWB) has issued 'fraud denials' of Dilorio's award applications and that SEC officials (Levenson, Best, Goodman, etc.) have criminally obstructed his investigations for years.
